channel.title: Should I repair this bike?
channel.description:
My dad bought this years ago for $5 at a garage sale. Although it's very old, the bike is one of the more expensive brands here in Australia. I don't need a bike, neither will I ride it very often but I have a lot of free time on my hands these days.
[img]http://img193.imageshack.us/img193/5684/img0919oh.jpg[/img]
[img]http://img821.imageshack.us/img821/4056/img0920pl.jpg[/img]
[img]http://img684.imageshack.us/img684/6929/img0921y.jpg[/img]
[img]http://img830.imageshack.us/img830/3547/img0922c.jpg[/img]
[img]http://img855.imageshack.us/img855/9599/img0923x.jpg[/img]
All I would need is something to remove the rust, lubricant for the chain, new tires and a helmet.
That would cost me under $30, depending on how much helmets go for. Is it worth it?

item.title: Should I repair this bike?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:27, topic:423538”]Do people over there not just buy cheap gasoline powered motors that you can put on any bike? I can order those off ebay for around $20-$50 dollars new all the time.

Yes, I was referring to normal bicycles, that doesn’t sound too bad.[/quote]

We have gasoline powered bicycles too, but not many people use them. The electric motor assists you, it doesn’t work when you aren’t moving the pedals. It’s like riding your bike with a constant wind in your back. The reason they don’t buy petrol engines isn’t clear to me. I wouldn’t buy a petrol engine for my bike, because you look like a hobo if you do, but I wouldn’t be an E-bike either.

I guess any of the following reasons apply: The bike doesn’t look bad, usage is cheaper than a petrol engine, it doesn’t pollute on the spot (generating electricity pollutes, but I’d rather have a power plant outside of a city than lots of petrol engines in a city) and it doesn’t smell.

item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Moparisthebest:

It still seems like, again, unless used for competition or something, a $100 bike would do the exact same job as a $1000 one, I guess I just don’t see the point.

Obviously a new bike costs more than a used bike. Racing bikes that cost more than €1000,- have carbon components, which make them lighter. Obviously, the more expensive racing bikes have more expensive components, which ensure a smoother and faster ride.

E-bikes are expensive because of the motor and battery. Normal bicycles aren’t that expensive, and you could do with a cheap one. My normal bicycle put me back €150,- which isn’t that much.

item.title: Should I repair this bike?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

This ‘chain wax/lube’ stuff they are talking about may be good to lubricate it over the long-run, I don’t know, I’ve never used it. But you definitely need some type of penetrating oil (like WD-40) to initially break up the rust on the chain and the sprockets, it’s all I’ve ever used on bikes before.

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:22, topic:423538”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=526165.msg3836022#msg3836022 date=1322919207]
I can’t believe anyone would spend that much on a bicycle unless they were a hard-core racer or something! The most I’ve ever spent on a bike is $100 (on sale from $250), but most of my bikes when I was younger were just bought used for $5-$15, and they all worked just fine.
[/quote]

Like Radeon said, we Europeans (and especially the Dutch and Belgians) have a rich bicycle culture. I used my bike to go to elementary school, secondary school, and still to go to the busstop now that I go to higher education. Although public transport is mostly used by students, it isn’t like in the US where schools pick children up with a bus.

My household, consisting of my parents and myself, own a total of 7 bicycles. I have 2 racing bicycles and a normal bicycle. My father has 2 MTB’s, and my mother has two normal bicycles. The racers and the MTB’s are shared between me and my father. Our bicycle to household members ratio is quite high, even to Dutch standards, but almost every Dutch citizen owns at least one bicycle. The newest trend is the electrical bicycle, where a motor assists you. They cost well in excess of €1000,- Popular ones reach €2000,-[/quote]
It still seems like, again, unless used for competition or something, a $100 bike would do the exact same job as a $1000 one, I guess I just don’t see the point.

item.title: Should I repair this bike?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

For exercise, you’d really want a smooth ride. If it can give you that in this condition, then don’t bother replacing the gears and chain. I started out with a €150,- bike. It was in better condition than yours is, but it still is no match for my new one, which only costed me €700,-. To be honest, my old one had down tube shifters, so you can imagine what an old piece of shit that was.

I really don’t think that amount of surface rust will cause a problem, and probably a good soaking with WD40 and a few rides will wear it right off anyhow.

I can’t believe anyone would spend that much on a bicycle unless they were a hard-core racer or something! The most I’ve ever spent on a bike is $100 (on sale from $250), but most of my bikes when I was younger were just bought used for $5-$15, and they all worked just fine.

item.title: Should I repair this bike?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Radeon, post:14, topic:423538”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=526165.msg3833846#msg3833846 date=1322767150]

I wouldn’t replace the gears as that would drive the cost up enough not to make it worth restoring.

Depends on condition of crank set and pedal arms, also wear on chain, HF with the rear freewheel (under 9 gears?) that looks fucked.

Why would you need more than 9 gears? confused face/

Just like RSC said, not wearing a helmet is dangerous. Also the police here will fine you for not wearing one.

What will you be using it for (school/job, or racing)? If you want to race with it, you’ll want the thing to ride as smooth as possible, so any rust on the chain/gears will slow you down (or tire you out faster). And how is the terrain around your place? I have 9 gears, and on my previous bike I had 7. The two extra only come in use when going up mountains. Too bad there aren’t any in a 200km radius.
[/quote]

For the time being, only exercise and fresh air. If I don’t feel the bike is too goofy, I might eventually ride to the train station for university.

The terrain here is entirely flat, I don’t think I’d actually ever need to change any gears.[/quote]

For exercise, you’d really want a smooth ride. If it can give you that in this condition, then don’t bother replacing the gears and chain. I started out with a €150,- bike. It was in better condition than yours is, but it still is no match for my new one, which only costed me €700,-. To be honest, my old one had down tube shifters, so you can imagine what an old piece of shit that was.

Clean the cassette and chain, and take it for a spin. Maybe just removing the rust will suffice.

You won’t need more than 9 gears. On flat terrain, only gears 3-9 come in use. 8 and 9 probably require you to switch gears on the crankset first, which only happens when you go faster than about 30km/h.

The bike doesn’t look like it’s been used for racing though. When racing, you put slicks on your bike, not tires with profile. You put a saddle on it that will make you sterile if you sit on it too long, and pedals that give more grip.

item.title: Should I repair this bike?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:423538”]Others have basically said this, but I’ll echo it.

You don’t need to remove the rust to ride it, and if the tires and tubes will hold air, you don’t need to replace them either, and if they won’t hold air, you can also just put a $5 tube inside them if the tread is sufficient for your needs. All that chain/gear setup needs is a few sprays with a penetrating oil like WD-40, that you can get a generic version of from the dollar store around here for less than $3. The helmet is probably the most expensive part of the ‘repair’, but don’t be an idiot, wear one. It doesn’t look like a super-expensive bike, so don’t spend a lot on it, just have fun.[/quote]

Yeah that sums it up. Gonna go get me some WD40 and I’ll settle with any other imperfections.
